review_blob: On tap @ Black Raven. Pours clear bright dark orange with next to no head, super thin white lacing. Aroma is crisp fresh melon and dark lemon, dry earthy oaky notes with substantial yeasty farmhouse funk. Taste is clean, light pale malt up front, earthy super dry finish, just a hint of that yeasty finish so evident in the nose. No sourness from the Brett, but a clean pleasant dryness that really allows this beer to shine. Great beer.

On tap @ Black Raven. Pours clear bright dark orange with next to no head, super thin white lacing. Aroma is crisp fresh melon and dark lemon, dry earthy oaky notes with substantial yeasty farmhouse funk. Taste is clean, light pale malt up front, earthy super dry finish, just a hint of that yeasty finish so evident in the nose. No sourness from the Brett, but a clean pleasant dryness that really allows this beer to shine. Great beer.

On tap @ Black Raven. Pours slightly hazy medium golden with thin white head. Aroma is rather harsh sharp earthy hops up front, floral and grassy, lighter citrus notes on the back. Taste is clean light pale malt, juicy citrus notes mid palate, lots of mellow tangerine, grapefruit, and blood orange citrus flavor. Definitely some odd, off notes here; but some amazing citrus depth and complexity that makes this appealing. Interesting beer, for sure, I liked this.
beer_name: Black Raven Flock Party Anniversary Ale

review_blob: On tap @ Perihelion. Pours hazy medium orange with thin lacy white head. Aroma is medium caramel malt, light citrus and tangerine notes from the hops. Taste is clean light toasted caramel malt, medium earthy hops with fresh floral notes on the finish. Fairly low abv for a IPA, but nice balance and solid throughout.

On tap @ Slow Boat. Pours bright yellow golden with medium lacy white head. Aroma is thin sweet pale malt, big piney herbal hops. Taste is medium crystal malt; big earthy resinous hops with loads of bitterness. Solid IPA, did not like this one quite as much as other recent Cloudburst offerings. Still, really solid IPA.

12 oz can from Reubens. Pours heavily hazy pale orange with medium white head that laces well. Aroma is big fresh citrusy hops; grapefruit, lemon zest, and tangerine notes stand out. Taste is clean, thin pale malt - totally lacking in the thin grainy notes that usually annoy me with Session IPAs. Hops are the star here, lots of fresh juicy citrus notes, lightly dank and piney on the back. Amazing hop flavor and balance for a sub 5% beer. Easily the best Session IPA Ive ever had; and the equal of Hop Tropic, Triumvirate, Crikey, etc. in the Reubens stable.

On tap @ Reubens. Pours hazy bright golden yellow with thin white head. Aroma is dry, lightly sweet crystal malt; big fresh floral notes, light saison yeast on the back. Taste is sweet very light crystal malt up front, juicy apple and mango notes mid-palate, a hint of oakiness, dry white pepper, super clean finish. Oak notes are perhaps a bit less than I expected, nonetheless this is delicious!

On tap @ The Yard. Pours slightly hazy dark orange with a reddish tint, creamy white head. Aroma is sweet toasted caramel malt, earthy hops with a fruity citrus note. Taste is likewise - caramel malt has deep roasted notes that play nicely with the sweetness. Hops are punchy and bitter, pine and grapefruit flavors standout. Lingers lightly bitter through the finish. Up there with Cloudbursts best IPAs, which is to say this is damn good.

16 can, served up in a tulip glass. Pours lightly hazy bright orange copper with thin lacy white head. Aroma is thin light caramel malt, fresh resinous hops, grapefruit pith and orange zest notes. Taste is more of a lift to medium bodied pale malt, restrained sweetness. Hops are sharply grassy and piney up front, then fade to a dank earthiness that lingers slightly bitter through the finish. Very easy drinking, seems much smaller than 7.2%. Well balanced. Bonus points for the cool color-changing can, Fort Georges creative is top notch yet again.

On tap @ Three Magnets. Pours slightly hazy medium golden with thick off-white head that laces heavily. Aroma is lightly toasty caramel malt, bright fresh citrusy hops. Taste is similar - relatively thick malt base, creamy body, light pine, grass, and citrus from the hops, mildly dank on the finish with slight lingering bitterness. Solid beer, pretty close to IPA territory.
beer_name: Three Magnets Eastside Club Pale Ale

review_blob: On tap @ Breakside. Pours milky whitish yellow with medium white head that fades quickly. Aroma is light caramel malt, big yeasty flavor, sweet light citrus - orange and lemon flavors stand out. Taste is big creamy rich mouthfeel, fresh fruity hops with solid melon and orange notes, dry slightly oaky finish. Yet another entry into the new milky "East Coast IPA" pantheon. Tasty beer, adds some diversity to the IPA landscape.
beer_name: Breakside / Fat Heads Pulp Free IPA

review_blob: On tap @ Breakside. Pours clear light yellowish golden with thin lacy white head. Aroma is fresh crisp hops, grassy and lightly vegetal. Taste is lightly sweet golden/pale malt, fresh vegetal hops, light pine. This tastes like a slightly de-tuned India Golden Ale from these guys. Good flavor here, the malt does disappear a bit, the IGA seems better balanced in that regard.

On tap @ Great Notion. Listed at 8.5% abv here. Pours deep brownish black with very thin mocha head. Aroma is roasty dark chocolate malt, some French roast coffee, and huge sweet maple syrup flavor. Taste is likewise - smooth and creamy mouthfeel, notes of vanilla, caramel; lightly charred chocolate malt on the finish. Plenty of maple syrup here too, though quite a bit less than the nose, this is actually fairly balanced. Interesting beer, well done.
beer_name: Great Notion Double Stack Northwest Breakfast Stout

review_blob: On tap @ Upright. Pours clear pale golden orange with thin white head. Aroma is tart cherries, light leathery red wine barrel notes. Taste is super crisp tartness up front, lacking in notable sour pucker though. Fresh cherries sit in the background. Excellent beer.

On tap @ Upright. Pours clear thin pale yellow with new head. Aroma is thin malt, faint tartness, light saison yeast. Taste is similar - fairly hoppy for a saison, juicy melon, dry finish. Clean, easy drinking, light funk on the finish. Nice.

On tap @ The Commons. Pours slightly hazy golden yellow with medium white head that fades quickly. Aroma is dry sweet light pale malt, just a hint of saison funk, not enough to match the malt sweetness though. Taste is clean, dry, light crystal malt - oddly no sweetness whatsoever... Saison yeast is present on the finish, although even lighter than the nose. Clean, refreshing, super easy drinking saison. Cant decide if this is just super clean saison; or a yeasty pale... either way, nice drinker.

On nitro @ Reubens. Pours inky dark black with thick mocha head that fades to a still substantial one. Aroma is light but roasty dark chocolate malt, rich creamy dairy notes, a bit of espresso. Taste is thick, roasty milk chocolate; super heavy rich mouthfeel. Tons of creaminess to cut the dark malt. Light sweetness, oaky and dry on the finish. Solid milk stout, a bit sweet and out of Reubens typical repertoire (my own, as well...) but nice.

On tap @ Reubens. Pours almost opaque reddish brown with thin creamy mocha head. Aroma is sweet roasty dark caramel malt; lots of fig, raisin, and molasses. Taste is toasted dark caramel malt, much less sweet than the nose. Creamy body while also being a bit thin for the style and abv. Notes of oak, bittersweet chocolate, and toffee are notable. Quite amazing how much more rich the nose is here vs. the actual flavor. Still, tasty beer.

On tap @ Reubens. Pours dark brownish black with medium creamy off-white head that laces well. Aroma is roasty dark chocolate malt, then lightly citrusy hops on the back. Taste is clean, creamy roasted dark malt, mild but noticeable chocolate flavor in the body. Hops are crisp with tons of juicy citrus, very mild lingering bitterness on the finish. Most CDAs, particularly imperial ones, are crushingly bitter such that the dark malt flavor is ruined - not so here! Great beer, much easier drinking than the 8% abv would suggest too.

On tap @ Reubens. Pours slightly hazy orange copper with medium lacy off-white head. Aroma is very faint malt and earthy, fresh crisp hops. Taste is light lager malt up front, although you can barely make it out before being slammed with hops. Hops are grassy, sharply vegetal, and linger bitter well through the finish. I didnt get the off notes that others are picking up on this, but the inherent limitation of a light lager malt to stand up to heavy hopping does seem obvious.

On tap @ Lindas. Pours clear pale yellow with medium white head. Aroma is light grassy hops, just a hint of grain. Taste is crisp, clean lager malt, slight note of corn; otherwise the hops are allowed to shine - fresh, grassy, with a light trailing vegetal note. Very juicy and hoppy for the style. Clean, super drinkable, perfect on a warm day.

On tap @ Fremont. Pours clear bright golden copper with very thin white head. Aroma is sweet medium caramel malt, fresh juicy citrusy hops - hefty grapefruit and mango notes. Taste is spot on - malt is sweet, lightly sugary; hops are fresh and floral, tons of juicy citrus with a faint dankness on the back. Nice, clean, sweet malt adds balance but these Citra hops are the star here. Juicy, solid, like this a lot. Curious to see how this is received in Oregon; no shortage of amazing IPAs there.

On tap @ Fremont. Pours hazy pale yellow golden with very thin white head. Aroma is pulpy citrus, lightly tart on the back, strong fresh grapefruit note that lingers. Taste is similar - lightly bodied with tart grapefruit and lemon flavors. Tartness is restrained and follows through the finish just slightly. Very clean and refreshing, the grapefruit works outstandingly here.

On tap @ Chucks 85th. Pours bright lightly hazy pale golden with minimal head. Aroma is sharp earthy and dark citrusy hops, little malt to speak of. Taste is clean, sweet dark caramel malt; earthy and toasty notes underneath, crisp bitter hops on the back. Fresh pine and grapefruit stand out. Solid DIPA, well balanced for the style.

22 oz bomber, served in a tulip. Pours clear bright deep orange with thick creamy off-white head that laces well. Aroma is sweet caramel malt, fresh earthy hops with light dank and grapefruity undertone. Taste is similar - malt has a light crisp sugary sweetness, hops are swiftly bitter up front and fade to an earthy slightly funky taste that lingers through the finish. Grapefruit and pine sap flavors stand out. Not quite as clean as Fresh Squeezed, but I liked this a bit better, seems a bit more rustic and less processed.

On tap @ Brouwers. Pours slightly hazy yellowish golden with creamy white head. Aroma is dank earthy citrusy hops. Taste is medium caramel malt, hefty without being too sweet. Super dry on the back, with big grapefruit and lemon notes from the hops, lots of hop juiciness. Solid, though not as good as some of Cloudbursts standard IPAs.

On tap @ Collins Pub. Pours bright yellow golden with medium creamy white head that laces heavily. Aroma is sweet pale malt, lightly dank earthy citrusy hops on the back. Taste is likewise - hops are juicy with tons of citrus; grapefruit and pine flavors stand out. Ive seen this listed as both a pale and IPA, in most of the world this would be solidly in the IPA category; though if you like hops its quite the pale ale. I continue to be impressed with Melvin, their lineup is incredibly solid.

On tap @ Safeco Field. Pours bright golden amber with thin lacy off-white head. Aroma is light caramel malt, faint toastiness, juicy hops. Taste is lightly sweet caramel malt, nice roasty notes, juicy citrusy hops. Bitterness is restrained, grapefruit and orange from the hops really shines on the dry finish. I would probably still take Lucille over this, takes the flavors from Johnny Utah and makes it into more of an IPA.

On tap @ Chucks CD. Pours clear golden yellow with thin lacy white head. Aroma is sweet pale malt, crisp light citrusy hops. Taste is syrupy pale malt, lightly dank earthy hops with nice lemon and mango hop flavors. Just a hint of bitterness on the finish, which lingers slightly afterwards. Very light bodied for the abv, yet still flavorful with punchy citrusy hops and sweet pale malt. A bit odd for a DIPA, but I liked this.
beer_name: Three Magnets Big Juice Double IPA

review_blob: On tap @ Beer Junction. Pours dark almost opaque mahogany with medium dark cream colored head that fades to a thin oily rim. Aroma is big sweet boozy toasted dark caramel malt, oak, molasses, soy sauce, bourbon, port. Taste is largely similar; vanilla, raisin, and dark fruit notes are more prominent here. Fairly thin mouthfeel, though it does open up into richness as it warms. I found this less boozy than regular BCBS. Great sipper.

2013 version on tap @ Brouwers. Pours inky watery blackish brown with medium mocha head that fades quickly. Aroma is dry lightly roasty dark chocolate malt, heavily oaky mid-palate, lightly boozy on the finish. Taste is smooth creamy oatmeal malt, rich milk chocolate, light bourbon and barrel notes. Obviously not as big as most of the other FW barrel-aged offerings, still has plenty of flavor. Though clearly a smaller beer than Parabola or the barleywines.

On tap @ Brouwers. Pours almost opaque brownish red with thick off-white head that fades quickly. Aroma is huge, rippling waves of bourbon; syrupy sweetness, oak, leather; earthy and dry on the back. Taste is rich, toasty caramel malt; dry and oaky, light smoke mid-palate, sweet vanilla and molasses on the back. Listed as an imperial brown here, which is deceptive. This is straight barleywine, and a boozy one at that. The amount of bourbon flavor from the barrels is simply amazing, if anything makes the 13.8% abv listed seem conservative. Quite a beer.
beer_name: Firestone Walker Bravo - Evan Williams 30 Year Barrel

review_blob: On tap @ Brouwers. Pours thick blackish brown with medium creamy mocha head that fades quickly, nice lacing. Aroma is rich creamy chocolate, cocoa nibs, fresh coffee, oak, dark molasses. Taste is big, rich fudgy chocolate; fresh roasty coffee, oaky and dry on the back. Layers upon layers of chocolate. Impressive beer. Coffee melds well with the base Parabola, otherwise this carries the same flavors though with a notably richer chocolate flavor. Bourbon notes are there, but dominated by the chocolate and coffee.

12 oz bottle from who knows. Pours hazy orange copper with medium creamy eggshell head. Aroma is sweet oaky caramel malt, light Belgian yeast, faint dry hops. Taste is sweet, faintly boozy caramel malt, dry and oaky mid-palate; funky Belgian yeast, crisp dry hops on the finish. Solid beer, probably the prototype for Belgian IPAs. Boozy enough to be a double as well.

On tap @ Chucks 85th. Pours clear light yellow with very thin white head. Aroma is light crisp malt, corn dominates the back. Taste is thin clean malt, decided corn flavor mid-palate; dry, clean, and earthy on the finish. Clean and easy-drinking throughout. Not super flavorful, but quite solid for a Pilsner.

On tap @ Chucks 85th. Pours dark thick brown with oily light mocha head that lingers. Aroma is huge fresh hazelnuts, some coffee; but honestly a staggering amount of hazelnut aroma. Taste is sweet, lightly roasty chocolate malt, mild earthy coffee notes mid-palate, then big rich hazelnut flavor that lingers through the finish. Nice creamy mouthfeel. If you like hazelnuts, this beer is spot on. That said, it completely overwhelms the otherwise excellent imperial stout here, and isnt really balanced in any sense of the word. I do like hazelnuts, so this worked for me...

On tap @ Chucks 85th. Pots slightly hazy bright yellow with thin creamy white head. Aroma is thin pale malt, light lemony dry hops on the back. Taste is clean, very pale malt; earthy dry hops, bitter lemon rind hops that linger through the finish. Ok, hops kinda dominate a less interesting malt here.

On tap @ Chucks 85th. Pours hazy yellow golden with medium creamy white head. Aroma is lightly floral hops, some sweetness. Taste is thin pale malt, lightly juicy tropical hops with slight lingering bitterness. Nice creamy mouthfeel. As a session IPA, I love this. Otherwise a bit below the usual Cloudburst IPA standard.

On tap @ Chucks 85th. Pours hazy golden yellow with thin creamy white head. Aroma is lemon pith, just a hint of tartness, lightly sweet pale malt. Taste is light pale malt, earthy oaky dryness, fresh lemony hops, tart without being sour at all. Nice IPA twist.

On tap @ Chucks 85th. Pours clear pale orange golden with thin white head. Aroma is juicy mango hops with a decided vegetal grassy note. Taste is clean light caramel malt; hops are dank and vegetal, mango notes are present though less so than the nose. Solid IPA, Id rank this as only a slight improvement over Hop Lava.

Growler served into a pint glass. Pours clear bright orange copper with medium white head. Aroma is sweet caramel malt; big juicy floral grapefruit and mango hops. Taste is similar - clean and almost syrupy sweet malt followed by those juicy hop notes. Dry piney notes linger through the finish with sustained bitterness. Hefty malt balances well though. Really nice IPA from Stoup.

On tap @ Chucks 85th. Pours thick inky brownish black with medium creamy mocha head that laces well. Aroma is dark heavily roasted malt, big dark chocolate, loads of fresh-roasted espresso and milk. Taste is thick, heavy dark chocolate malt, lightly charred; oaky and dry on the back with heavy espresso notes that linger through the finish. Rich, super tasty, hard to complain about this - but lacking the balance overall of standard Speedway.

On tap @ Chucks 85th. Pours watery dark blackish brown with thin off-white head. Aroma is heavily roasted dark chocolate malts, nice toffee and caramel notes. Just a hint of smoke on the back. Taste is same dark roasty malts, super creamy mouthfeel, nice coffee and chocolate. Smoke is more obvious here, though doesnt dominate. Dry, clean finish. Pretty close to the Stoup Robust Porter, not at all a bad thing.

22 oz bottle, served in a small snifter. Pours dark watery brownish black with thin creamy off-white head. Aroma is roasty dark malts, sweet bourbony oaky notes on the back, lighter throughout. Taste is rich roasty charred malts, oaky sweet caramel, faintly salty throughout. Dry light hints of bourbon on the finish. Ok, solid flavors, needs more malt body and was expecting a bit more bourbon after a year in barrels.
beer_name: Breakside Salted Caramel Stout - Bourbon Barrel-Aged

review_blob: On tap @ BXLDR. Pours lightly hazy bright golden with thin lacy white head. Aroma is sweet, relatively subtle caramel malt; dark citrusy dank hops on the back. Taste is sticky malt; juicy, floral hops; earthy mid-palate; oaky, dry, and clean on the finish. Very drinkable in spite of the big abv. Punchy bitterness, but super enjoyable.

On tap @ BXLDR. Pours clear watery reddish dark cola brown with very little head. Aroma is bright red berries, light leather, slight port barrel notes on the back. Taste is thin, watery malt; oaky and dry on the finish. Subtle, light tartness that fades quickly to a clean finish. Not a big beer, but lots of enjoyable flavors here.

On tap @ BXLDR. Pours bright reddish brown with thin creamy off-white head. Aroma is rich, lightly toasted caramel malt; dry with light farmhouse funk on the back. Taste is sweet, syrupy malt - fairly boozy. Dry and earthy on the finish, light notes of leather, dark berries, and oak. Interesting beer, very rich for the style, would be tough to do more than one.
beer_name: J. Wakefield I Think Im French

review_blob: UPDATED: MAR 29, 2016
beer_name: Founders Backstage Series # 7: Mango Magnifico con Calor

review_blob: Can @ The Porch Key West. Pours clear dark copper with thin white head. Aroma is big sweet sticky caramel malt, oaky and dry on the finish. Taste is similar - oaky, sweet, toasty caramel malt; dry with big piney and aromatic hops on the finish. I didnt get much honey. Sweet and sticky throughout, tons of rich flavor.

On tap @ Abbey Brewing. Pours light yellow golden with thick white head that fades quickly, laces very well. Aroma is big juicy citrusy hops, light bitterness, lots of orange, grapefruit, and mango come through. Taste is light and thin crystal malt; followed by those same big juicy citrus hops. Dry with slight lingering bitterness on the finish. Hops really shine against the light malt bill here.
beer_name: M.I.A. Brewing / Coppertail Crossing Streams IPA
